Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Noninvasive Focused Ultrasound for Chronic Pain

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants aged 18-65 with chronic pain were randomised

Participants.evidence: Participants aged 18-65 with chronic pain were randomised to receive either active or sham ultrasound stimulation.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either active or sham ultrasound stimulation

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates a noninvasive focused ultrasound approach to modulate the ACC for pain relief.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in pain intensity, measured using the Brief Pain Inventory over a 7-day period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Both participants and outcome assessors were blinded.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Active stimulation resulted in a 60% reduction in pain immediately post-intervention, 43% on day 1, and 33% on day 7. Sham stimulation resulted in reductions of 14.4%, 12.3%, and 6.6%, respectively. The effect size was significant (p < 0.05).

Harms.evidence: No serious adverse events were reported; mild side effects resolved within 24 hours.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the University of Utah.
